history.content:
It's very conceptual, the least math I've done for an upper-division class. The workload is a medium-length problem set each week, pretty manageable as long as you attend lectures. However, all questions are worded very... differently, so you basically must to go to office hours each week to figure out what the problems really ask. Once you get the hang of the wording, you'll learn a lot. 

The professor is brilliant, and his office hours and lectures teach you a ton. A lot of material is covered, and you should finish the class with a solid understanding of medical imaging concepts.

Make sure to take EE120 before you take it, it's extremely difficult to understand what's going on in the class without it.

children.subject:
It's possible and likely that since I took the class the professor has added more review and support in the beginning for those who haven't taken EE120. It is possible to take it without EE120, but that would require a significant amount of extra work.

It's cross-enrolled with BioE, so a lot of the BioE students also take EE120 before EEC145B, and I believe even the ones who don't learn those concepts in other BioE prereq classes.

I took EEC145B without taking EE120. I spent many more hours each week on the class than I should have as a result, and a lot of the big ideas did not really make sense to me until I took EE120 the following semester. Most of the other students had already taken EE120, and most who didn't take EE120 dropped a few weeks in. However, I really did enjoy the class. Looking back, I would have had a much easier time and enjoyed it even more if I had stronger foundations. With EE120, it's a light tech. Without EE120, it's a heavy tech.

The intuition you get from EE120 is most important. EECS16B touches on the DFT, but doesn't really teach you discrete and continuous Fourier transforms, sampling theory, and other concepts that EE120 builds up from scratch.

I second this. I recently emailed the professor about possible alternate final times and he added : "In the last few years, I have genuine concerns with the math preparation for undergrads from both departments. Be sure you have some analog convolution and Fourier Transform background.  EE120 is WAY better than EE16a/b.  Students from EECS have been struggling in the class because of the math background in EE16a/b, unfortunately.  I do use a bit of linear algebra (which is covered okay in EE16a/b) but convolution and FT are the power tools."
Thanks! @Anon Mouse when did you take this class?

Thanks! Could you please elaborate on what concepts from EE 120 are needed for this class? I was under the impression that the only official prerequisites for this class were EECS 16A&B, based off classes.berkeley.edu.

history.content: Has anyone here taken EECS C145B in the past, and can comment on its workload and rigor? Thanks
history.subject: EECS C145B
